utterances.utterance: You're going to pick someone like Lynne Patton who was basically the wedding planner for Eric Trump, with no experience whatsoever working at HUD. And that's who you're going to trot out? Someone who's like the personal assistant of the family to say, well he's not racist?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Your response?

utterances.speaker: PATTON
utterances.utterance: You know, first of all, Laura, it's unfortunate, you're a real journalist. There are so many glorified bloggers posing as journalists these days. If they took the time to not be lazy and Google Eric Trump's real wedding planner, they would see 2014 article, long before the president even won, that was an interview with the real wedding planner in People magazine. So you know, these are just people that are just internet parrots. And quite frankly, if I cared what overpaid pundits and internet trolls said, I would have stopped getting out of bed three years ago. You know, their opinion means nothing, basically. You know, like the president, we're moving forward. You know, again...

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Lynne -- Lynne, the great thing is that you're just -- I had a chance meet you once I think a long time ago at Trump Tower. But you're just someone whose not - you're not going to be silenced, you're not going to be cowed, you're not intimidated. And I say the same thing, if you're a conservative woman, and you support conservative ideas, you support Trump, you're not real woman in their eyes.

utterances.speaker: PATTON
utterances.utterance: No, there's no march...

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: And it is unacceptable.

utterances.speaker: PATTON
utterances.utterance: There's no march for us, Laura.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Unacceptable.

utterances.speaker: PATTON
utterances.utterance: Unacceptable.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Lynne, thank you for joining us tonight, we really appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: PATTON
utterances.utterance: Thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: It wasn't just Lynne Patton, of course, who came under fire yesterday -- absolutely -- for her appearance yesterday.

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN
utterances.utterance: Republican Congressman Mark Meadows, he brought a special guest, Lynne Patton, who's a Trump administration official, as if she were a live prop, trotting her out in an attempt to prove that this president couldn't possibly be a racist. I have a black friend, prop. A black employee, prop. Come on, y'all.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Come on, y'all.

utterances.speaker: REP. MARK MEADOWS, R-N.C.
utterances.utterance: Well, I mean, listen, we can talk about this all night long. And certainly there's been a lot of headlines today. I think the bottom line is this, is in Congress what we need to do is seek the truth. And the truth is, is that Michael Cohen was given a 30-minute opening statement by the Democrats that I don't remember -- I've been on the Oversight Committee for over six years now. There has never been an opening testimony of 30 minutes. And then a closing of another ten minutes. And so, you know, it's really --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Do you think someone helped him with his -- with his testimony? Democrats (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: MEADOWS
utterances.utterance: Well, I think Lanny Davis wrote the testimony when you look at it.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MEADOWS
utterances.utterance: It was really a combination of some of Michael Cohen's personal knowledge and then a whole lot of things that have been reported pulled into that, really designed to try to just damage this president.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: But --

utterances.speaker: MEADOWS
utterances.utterance: And we've seen that over and over again. But here's the -- here's the interesting thing. Jim Jordan and I have put forth a letter today citing six ways that Michael Cohen has contradicted himself and perhaps committed perjury. And so we've -- we committed that and sent that to the new attorney general for a criminal referral to have them look at it.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: What specifically?

utterances.speaker: MEADOWS
utterances.utterance: Well, you know, when you -- when you look at I -- John Solomon's (ph) already done some reporting on this. Just the one claim that he never wanted to work at the White House, it's -- it's been refuted over and over. I was refuted while well were in the hearing. And now I think John Solomon has between nine and a dozen people --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes. But he also refuted collusion, right? So he said a lot of things that were actually, I think, very positive to the president.

utterances.speaker: MEADOWS
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes. I mean --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Against the narrative of the left. I didn't see him collude, the whole phone call with Donnie Jr., all of this stuff --

utterances.speaker: MEADOWS
utterances.utterance: The timing of that phone call, too, if you look at it --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: So I think the Republicans are a bit of -- it's a bit of a pickle with Cohen, because some things he said, you want to say see, he said this. On other occasions, he's lying about that.

utterances.speaker: MEADOWS
utterances.utterance: And we can. But here's the other thing is you know that yesterday was his greatest attempt to do as much damage as he possibly could.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: This is by a payback.

utterances.speaker: MEADOWS
utterances.utterance: It really was.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Big-time payback to Trump.

utterances.speaker: MEADOWS
utterances.utterance: But here's the thing is he came in and said I'm a new man and all of that. He ought to tell the Southern District of New York that because they asked him to cooperate and he refused to do that. And when you look at that, if you read --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Aren't they still working with him?

utterances.speaker: MEADOWS
utterances.utterance: But they put in there, it was very, very strong wording that he is just not cooperating.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Were you hugging the Congresswoman Tlaib on the floor of the House?

utterances.speaker: MEADOWS
utterances.utterance: I went down today -- listen, we are all about being civil. She offered and apology.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: She was an outrage. I know you are being kind. Her comments to you were outrageous.

utterances.speaker: MEADOWS
utterances.utterance: Well, but at the same time, listen, we are in a civil society. That's what separates us from all other nations is a civil society. And I just felt compelled to go down and offer a hand of friendship and say, listen, if there was anything that I did that personally offended you, it didn't come from my heart. She hugged me, and certainly we looked at moving forward to hopefully work --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: That is good, because the word "racist" is thrown around way too casually.

utterances.speaker: MEADOWS
utterances.utterance: Fortunately for me I know that I'm not a racist. If you --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: But even that, that is so defensive. When they call you a racist, you're the racist for bringing up race here. The president's record should stand on his own. Don't go back to I was driving in Chicago and he said something -- I find that all --

utterances.speaker: MEADOWS
utterances.utterance: We all say hurtful things. And so it's more important that we reconcile.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Congressman, I'm glad you had the hug, a kumbaya moment. Good for you. You are the bigger man. Thank you so much for joining us. And Michael Cohen did create that stir on Capitol Hill yesterday. We have more on that with Chris Christie when we come back.

utterances.speaker: MICHAEL COHEN, FORMER TRUMP ATTORNEY
utterances.utterance: I did not want to go the White House. I was offered jobs. I have not been asked.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: If you were asked --

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.utterance: You know I don't lie. There is absolutely a chance he's going to ask me. I certainly hope so.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Would you go?

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.utterance: A hundred percent.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Well, that was just one of the little white lies Michael Cohen told in yesterday's hearing. But does that discredit his entire testimony? As I said earlier, some of the things he said about no collusion, that was actually helpful to Trump. So where does this leave us all at this point? Michael Cohen testifying behind closed doors today on Capitol Hill. Joining me now with answers, Chris Christie, former governor of New Jersey, author of the new book "Let Me Finish, Trump, The Kushners, Bannon, New Jersey, and The Power of In Your Face Politics." Governor, thanks for being here. In your opinion, what is the most important takeaway for President Trump from yesterday's hearing? Then we're going to move to this North Korea deal.

utterances.speaker: CHRIS CHRISTIE, R-N.J., FORMER GOVERNOR
utterances.utterance: I don't know if there's any just one, Laura. I think the fact that Michael Cohen said that there were multiple reasons for the payments to Stormy Daniels, that support's the president view that he just had one reason, and that was to protect his wife from that. And Michael Cohen saying the story about lying to the first lady seems to back that up. And I think there's no way any responsible prosecutor would make a case on that. Secondly, him saying that the president didn't direct him to lie, that somehow he understood some type of code words or signals. No one is going to believe somebody who is a perjurer and a thief and convict someone based upon his read of code words. And I think the fact that Cohen said there was no collusion. My frustration yesterday, Laura, was that nobody on the Republican side defended on the president on the merits, on the substance. After two or three congresspeople on our side said Michael Cohen is a liar and thief. I get it. OK, he's a liar and a thief. Now let's get to the stuff you were talking about, which was there was good part of his testimony that we should be trumpeting and hitting back on to get into the record more clearly for the American people. And I think the Congress failed miserably on that yesterday.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: You know what I always say? In these high-stakes hearing it would be better if the Congressmen had more humility, maybe. It would be better if they brought in a professional prosecutor, someone who does it every day, or former prosecutor, every single day. And that is how you run these things, because Trey Gowdy, I love them all, but unless you do it every day all the time you get a little rusty.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: No doubt.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: And politics get in the way. I think they missed opportunities on that.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: You got it both right, Laura. They not only missed opportunities because they don't have the muscle memory of doing it every day, but also the politics gets in the way and they all want to get the bite that they think is going to get on the news of them raising their voices or yelling or screaming. In the end I thought some of the better points that were made yesterday were made quietly and thoughtfully. And I think we would have been much better off if we had people on our side who are doing more of that. We had to do some of the Cohen bashing stuff, of course. He deserves it, he's earned it. But we didn't do as much as we did. We should have got on to the substance.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Did you know Michael Cohen? I only met him a few times. I remember I ran into him a few times. I didn't really know much about him. Did you ever have any interactions with him?

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: Very briefly. I think I had something similar to you, Laura. I would see him in Trump Tower when I was there, we'd say hello to each other. But I don't think I was ever in a meeting with Michael Cohen.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: It always also goes back to the people you hire. It's very important to get the hires right. And I think we have all done that, we've all hired people, like, that was a mistake. In the end, it was a bad hire. In the end, Jeff Sessions not the right person to be attorney general.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: You know I was hoping for you to be attorney general.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: Listen, I know. Listen, he was a bad hire. Tom Price was a bad hire. There was a number of bad hires early on in this administration. And that is what we talked about in the book that just crippled the president's ability to be even more effective than he has been. To me that is the thing he has got -- that he started to turn around in second half of the second term, but needs to do even more of it.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: And, Governor, we're going to get into the southern district of New York, some of your comments about where those landmines might be for the administration and a lot more, including the wanton use of the race card against this president and his administration. You have known the president for a long time. Chris Christie is going to stay with us over the break. Don't go away.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Is there any other wrongdoing or illegal act that you are aware of regarding Donald Trump that we haven't yet discussed today?

utterances.speaker: MICHAEL COHEN, FORMER TRUMP ATTORNEY
utterances.utterance: Yes. And, again, those are part of the investigation that is currently being looked at by the Southern District of New York.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Back with us now, Chris Christie, former governor of New Jersey. Governor, you said the SDNY is going to try to indict the president when he leaves office. On what grounds?

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: No. What I said was that that's the investigation he should be most concerned about both for him and for the people around him because they have no limit to what they can look at, Laura. The SDNY is not like Bob Mueller who is restricted to just looking at Russia and Russia-related items. The SDNY can look at anything they want to look at. They have two tour guides. What I said is, they can't indict the president until he leaves office because there is a clear Justice Department ruling that says sitting presidents cannot be indicted. And I don't think there could be any way that the U.S. attorney in the southern district would try to violate that rule. And if they did, I think Bill Barr would stop them.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I think Ken Delaney of NBC was trying to characterize your comments. I want to move on to a story that just broke tonight about Jared Kushner's security clearance, Governor Christie. There was a report we will put up on the screen. Again, this is "New York Times" Maggie Haberman, "President Trump ordered his chief of staff to grant his son-in-law and senior adviser Jared Kushner a top secret security clearance last year, overruling concerns flagged by intel officials and the White House's top lawyer according to four people briefed on the matter. The disclose of the memo contradicts statements by the president who told the "New York Times" that he had no role in his son-in-law receiving clearance." Kushner's legal team responded, saying "In 2018 the White House and the security clearance officials affirmed that Mr. Kushner's security clearance was handled in the regular process with no pressure from anyone. That was conveyed to the media at the time," et cetera. Your reaction to this?

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: Listen, if true, it's bad. And it's bad in this respect. This is what I write about in the book, Laura. Having family in the administration is a very tough thing to deal with because now when Jared Kushner was not getting his security clearance, it's much more difficult for a president who is also a father-in-law to be objective about his son- in-law and his daughter. And so here's the problem. The president had the absolute right to give a security clearance to whoever he wanted to. But just say that is what you did. Don't say you had nothing to do with it. And Ivanka went on television and said that her father played no role in her security clearance or her husband's. Now, if this "Times" report is correct --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: She might not have knowledge of any of this. She doesn't necessarily have to know about it.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: Then just say you don't know. Just say you don't know. Don't affirmatively say he had no role. And the fact is that the problem here is that if in fact these memos exist as was reported in the story, from John Kelly and Don McGahn, this make what is the president said not true and what Ivanka said not true, when they didn't have to. Just say, listen, I decide who gets security clearance because I'm the president. I trust him. I need him. I want him. I'm giving it to them. End of discussion.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes. We all commit unforced errors in our lives. And it's unforced error.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: Right, that is my point.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: If the reporting is accurate. I would also say that Kushner, I know for a fact he had an incredible role in the Mexico trade deal. He is trying to do something extraordinary in the Middle East, very difficult obviously. And she is trying to do something extraordinary in expanding women's opportunities. Family members, not family members, I think people need to be judged on their results. But it does put people in difficult positions at different points in time.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: It just makes it hard, Laura, and that's why we haven't had family members in positions. Now what is going to happen -- one of the things from Cohen yesterday, now the House is going to subpoena them. And quite frankly for a House Overnight Committee, given that they have jobs in the administration, they are subject to the subpoenas, where Eric thought he would not be.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes, they are going to salivating at that opportunity, no doubt about it.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Governor Christie, thank you so much for joining us. We really appreciate it. And up next, why is Hollywood still defending Jussie Smollett? Raymond Arroyo is here with up to the minute details on what is happening. Don't go away.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Wait till you hear how the Hollywood reporter is attempting tonight to excuse Jussie Smollett's conduct in Chicago. Joining us now with all the details, Raymond Arroyo, FOX News contributor, "New York Times" the new and bestselling book, "Will Wilder, The Amulet of Power." Raymond, what is "The Hollywood Reporters'" rationale for defending Smollett?

utterances.speaker: RAYMOND ARROYO, CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: Laura, look, under the headline "I'm about to break, Jussie Smollett and the pressure of Hollywood fame," "The Hollywood Reporter" dug up a 2018 Billboard interview with Smollett where he says this. "I admit that I'm jealous, I admit that I'm insecure and that I'm not good at certain things." Then in a comment that didn't get much attention at the time, Smollett suggested that these pressures might be catching up to him. Quote, "I'm in my 30s and I'm trying my best to learn that I can't bend anymore. I'm about to break." The upshot here is the pressures of fames got the best of this guy and he snapped and then he faked or possibly faked this attack. Now some Hollywood heavyweights are defending Smollett, including Ellen Page.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: She was the worst of all.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: She is still saying in an op-ed I had no reason to doubt Jussie. She said it has raised the issue --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Raymond, she blamed Mike Pence. She was saying Mike Pence said something to inspire the attack. Shameful.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: And now Tyler Perry is weighing in. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: That's sad.

utterances.speaker: TYLER PERRY, ACTOR
utterances.utterance: He is adamant that he is telling the truth. Everybody that knows him that I know that I know, they all say he is not the type of person to ever do that. He is so convincing in his story that I'm just hoping and standing with him, hoping that it turns out in his favor.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Why is he hoping that this actor has endured a racist, homophobic attack? You know I love me some Tyler Perry. I love him. and the reason, he brings hope to people and lifts people and brings them together.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I like him, too. That is really disappointing.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: But to hear that is so disappointing. Remember also, it was the police superintendent, Eddie Johnson in Chicago, who said, quote, Smollett took advantage of the pain and the anger of racism to promote his career. This is not --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: We don't want racial attacks, hoaxes, racial attacks. But Tyler Perry, he's out there, he said it's the last Madea, right? He's retiring Madea from --

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: And the latest we are getting from Rafer Weigel, the Nigerian brothers, they are trying to pin it on them, saying they actually attacked Smollett and he mistook them for two white, MAGA-hatted assailants.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: And then he wrote the $3,500 for the five workout sessions?

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Workout sessions.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Those must be some good workout sessions.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: I don't want any kind of workouts like that. You'll find me at the "Madea's Family Funeral."

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Is that what it is called, "Madea's Family Funeral"?

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: "Madea's Family Funeral." Maybe Smollett should have been at "Madea's Family Funeral."

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: The left doesn't like Madea because they think it promotes bad stereotypes.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: That's what I mean. Spike Lee attacked Tyler Perry, saying that that this is racial stereotyping. Now they are going after "Green Book" for the same rationale. They don't like to bringing people together. And that is wrong. We need a narrative of brotherhood and unity.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Stay there. My special guest at CPAC is tonight's Last Bite.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: This is my daughter, Maria.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: This is the future, my friends. Our next generation is going to be better than we are. And I want the best for her.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: That was my daughter, Maria. I just had to bring her out on stage, a last-minute thought, and we did it. She enjoyed it, right, Raymond? Loved it. What a great moment. That's all the time we have tonight. Shannon Bream and the Fox News@Night Team take it from here. Content and Programming Copyright 2019 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED.
